choices.text: It causes Dorsiflexion of Foot at the Ankle Joint
It is supplied by Superficial Peroneal Nerve
It is the Strongest Tendon of the Human Body
Its inserts into the Upper Third of Calcaneus

questions.text: A 47-year-old obese man felt a snap in his right lower leg while playing squash and couldn’t continue the game further. He reached the emergency department with complaints of acute severe pain in his right lower leg and heel. The physician confirmed a diagnosis of an acute right Achilles tendon rupture, and the patient was immediately posted for open reparative surgery. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the Strongest Tendon of the Human Body

 

Option C:

 

  • Achilles tendon is formed by the union of tendons of Gastrocnemius, soleus and plantaris muscles.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It causes dorsiflexion of foot at the ankle joint: The Achilles tendon, formed by the confluence of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, is actually responsible for plantarflexion of the foot at the ankle joint, not dorsiflexion. Plantarflexion is the movement that points the toes downward, which is essential for actions like pushing off while walking or standing on tiptoes.

 

Option B. It is supplied by superficial peroneal nerve: The muscles that form the Achilles tendon, namely the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, are innervated by the tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve. The superficial peroneal nerve, on the other hand, primarily innervates muscles in the lateral compartment of the leg, which are involved in eversion of the foot.

 

Option D. It inserts into the upper third of calcaneus: The Achilles tendon actually inserts into the posterior aspect of the calcaneus, not specifically into the upper third. It attaches near the mid-region of the calcaneus, providing the leverage necessary for plantarflexion of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Achilles tendon is known to be the strongest and largest tendon in the human body.
  • It can withstand great tensile forces, which is essential for the transmission of forces from the calf muscles to the foot, enabling activities like running, jumping, and climbing.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1409

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a sedentary lifestyle presents with chronic lower extremity edema. On examination, his calf muscles appear underdeveloped. The physician explains the importance of a particular lower limb muscle in venous blood return from the lower extremities. Which muscle is often referred to as the "peripheral heart" due to its role in facilitating venous return?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Soleus

 

Option B:

 

  • The Soleus muscle, due to its constant activity and pumping action, is often referred to as the "peripheral heart," playing a crucial role in facilitating venous return from the lower extremities.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Although the gastrocnemius muscle assists in venous return by pumping blood towards the heart during movement, it is not typically referred to as the "peripheral heart." This term is more specifically associated with the soleus muscle.

 

Option C. The tibialis anterior is primarily involved in dorsiflexion of the foot and does not have a major role in facilitating venous return.

 

Option D. The primary function of the peroneus longus is to evert the foot and stabilize the ankle during walking. It is not significantly involved in aiding venous return.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The soleus muscle, due to its continuous slow-twitch muscle contractions, plays a significant role in pumping venous blood from the lower extremities back to the heart. This function is crucial, especially in individuals who are sedentary, to prevent venous stasis and related complications like edema.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 411.

choices.text: Soleus arises from Middle 1/3rd Shaft of Fibula
Soleus arises from Anterior Border of Tibia
In this case, the Tibial Nerve is compressed below the Tendinous Arch between Tibial & Fibular Origin of Soleus
The Peroneal Vessels accompany the Tibial Nerve beneath the Tendinous Arch

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman suffered from pain in the sole of her right foot, which was aggravated by active plantar flexion or passive extension of the ankle. Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging revealed a hypertrophic lesion in the right popliteus muscle. The tibial nerve was pushed posteriorly by the lesion and compressed by the arch of the soleus. The arch of the soleus was divided surgically. Pain was resolved immediately after the surgery, and significant neurologic recovery was observed 1 year after the surgical treatment. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In this case, the Tibial Nerve is compressed below the Tendinous Arch between Tibial & Fibular Origin of Soleus.

 

Option C:

 

  • Tibial nerve supplies muscles in the posterior compartment of leg which cause plantar flexion at ankle.
  • In this clinical case, a 65-year-old woman suffered from foot pain due to a lesion in the right popliteus muscle, which led to compression of the tibial nerve by the arch of the soleus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soleus Arises from Middle 1/3rd Shaft of Fibula: The soleus muscle is one of the muscles in the posterior compartment of the leg, playing a key role in plantarflexion of the foot. The soleus muscle does originate from the fibula, but not exclusively from the middle third. It arises from the head and upper quarter of the posterior surface of the fibula and also from the soleal line and the middle third of the medial border of the tibia.

 

Option B. Soleus Arises from Anterior Border of Tibia: The soleus does not arise from the anterior border of the tibia. It originates from the posterior aspect of the tibia, specifically from the soleal line and the middle third of the medial border.

 

Option D. The Peroneal Vessels Accompany the Tibial Nerve Beneath the Tendinous Arch: The peroneal vessels (fibular vessels) do not accompany the tibial nerve beneath the tendinous arch of the soleus. The tibial nerve runs in close proximity to the posterior tibial vessels in the posterior compartment of the leg.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The anatomical relationship between the soleus muscle and the tibial nerve is important in this case.
  • In this clinical scenario, the tibial nerve was compressed below the tendinous arch (also known as the soleus arch or the tendinous arch of the soleus), which is formed at the junction of the tibial and fibular origins of the soleus muscle.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 405

choices.text: Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament
Tibio-Calcaneal part of Deltoid Ligament
Tibio Talar part of Deltoid Ligament

questions.text: Under-21 Basketball Player sprained his Right Ankle after landing on an opponent’s Foot after a Jump Shot. His Ankle went over, and it was very Painful. The Ankle Swelled very quickly and he could not bear his weight. There was no evidence of fracture of lower limb bones in x-ray. This is the patient’s first ankle injury. Which structure related to the ankle joint has been injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament

 

Optino A:

 

  • The scenario described is a classic presentation of an ankle sprain, a common injury in sports, particularly basketball.
  • Anterior talofibular ligament extends forwards and medially from the anterior margin of the fibular malleolus to the adjacent lateral surface of the neck of talus.
  • It is a weak band and gets frequently torn due to over inversion during falls or twists.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tibio-calcaneal part of deltoid ligament: Deltoid ligament (medial ligament) of the ankle joint has superficial & deep parts. Superficial part includes Tibionavicular, Tibiocalcanean & posterior tibiotalar part. Deep part includes the Anterior tibiotalar ligament. This ligament is part of the medial deltoid ligament complex and is not typically injured in common lateral ankle sprains. Injuries to the deltoid ligament are less common and are usually associated with severe trauma or a high-energy mechanism, often involving eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Capsular ligament: Capsule of the ankle joint is thin in front and behind. It attaches to the periphery of the articular surface but in the anterior part, it extends somewhat to the dorsal rough surface of the neck of the talus. While the ankle joint capsule can be involved in a sprain, it is less specific than the ATFL for the type of injury described. The capsule surrounds the entire joint, and its injury usually occurs alongside more specific ligamentous injuries.

 

Option D. Tibio-talar part of deltoid ligament: This is another component of the medial deltoid ligament. As with the tibio-calcaneal part, it is more likely to be injured with eversion injuries, not the inversion injury described in this case.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral ligaments of the ankle joint are Anterior & Posterior talofibular ligaments, and Calcaneofibular ligament.
  • Anterior talo-fibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured ligament in lateral ankle sprains, which typically occur when the foot is plantarflexed and inverted (as might happen when landing awkwardly on someone else's foot).
  • The ATFL stabilizes the lateral aspect of the ankle and is particularly vulnerable in this position. Given the mechanism of injury described, this is the most likely structure to be injured.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1431
